<//body><//html><html><body><div class="homograph-entry">    
    <a id="knit_1"></a><h1 class="orth h1_entry">knit<span class="pron">(n<span class="underline"></span>t<span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knit" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30547/30547.mp3"></a>
</span>)</span></h1>
<div class="inflected_forms"><span class="var">Word forms:</span> <span class="infl">knits</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knit" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30548/30548.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">knitting</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knit" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30552/30552.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">knitted</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knit" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30549/30549.mp3"></a>
</span></div>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <div id="knit_1.1" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you <strong>knit</strong> something, especially an article of clothing, you make it from wool or a similar
               thread by using two knitting needles or a machine.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  I had endless hours to knit and sew.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  I have already started knitting baby clothes.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n n]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  She knitted him 10 pairs of socks to take with him.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n +  <em class="hi">for</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  During the war, Joan helped her mother knit scarves for soldiers.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span>-ed]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  She pushed up the sleeves of her grey knitted cardigan and got to work.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [Also <span class="smallcaps">V</span> n +  <em class="hi">into</em>]</span></li>
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> <strong>Knit</strong> is also a combining form.</span><span class="orth"><q>  Ferris wore a heavy knit sweater.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knit_1.8" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If someone or something <strong>knits</strong> things or people <strong>together</strong>, they make them fit or work together closely and successfully.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n with  <em class="hi">together</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  The best thing about sport is that it knits the whole family close together.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n +  <em class="hi">to/into</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  Ordinary people have some reservations about their president's drive to knit them
                  so closely to their neighbors.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [Also <span class="smallcaps">V</span> n]</span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knit_1.11" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">3. combining form</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> <strong>Knit</strong> is also a combining form.</span><span class="orth"><q>  ...a tightly knit society.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knit_1.13" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">4. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> When broken bones <strong>knit</strong>, the broken pieces grow together again.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> +  <em class="hi">together</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  The bone hasn't knitted together properly.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  ...broken bones that have failed to knit.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knit_1.16" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">5. phrase</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you <strong>knit</strong> your <strong>brows</strong> or <strong>knit</strong> your <strong>eyebrows</strong>, you frown because you are angry or worried.</span> (<span class="lbl register">literary</span>)<span class="orth"><q>  They knitted their brows and started to grumble.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  Billy's eyebrows knitted together in a little frown.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div></div>
<//body><//html><html><body><div class="homograph-entry">    
    <a id="knot_1"></a><h1 class="orth h1_entry">knot<span class="pron">(n<span class="underline"></span>t<span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knot" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30583/30583.mp3"></a>
</span>)</span></h1>
<div class="inflected_forms"><span class="var">Word forms:</span> <span class="infl">knots</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knot" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30584/30584.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">knotting</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knot" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30588/30588.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">knotted</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for knot" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/305/30585/30585.mp3"></a>
</span></div>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <div id="knot_1.1" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you tie a <strong>knot</strong> in a piece of string, rope, cloth, or other material, you pass one end or part of
               it through a loop and pull it tight.</span><span class="orth"><q>  One lace had broken and been tied in a knot.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.3" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you <strong>knot</strong> a piece of string, rope, cloth, or other material, you pass one end or part of it
               through a loop and pull it tight.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n with  <em class="hi">together</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  He knotted the laces securely together.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  He knotted the bandanna around his neck.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span>-ed]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  ...a knotted rope.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.7" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">3. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you feel a <strong>knot</strong> in your stomach, you get an uncomfortable tight feeling in your stomach, usually
               because you are afraid or excited.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">of</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  There was a knot of tension in his stomach.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.9" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">4. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If your stomach <strong>knots</strong> or if something <strong>knots</strong> it, it feels tight because you are afraid or excited.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  I felt my stomach knot with apprehension.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  The old dread knotted her stomach.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.12" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">5. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If part of your face or your muscles <strong>knot</strong>, they become tense, usually because you are worried or angry.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  His forehead knotted in a frown.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span>-ed]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  ...his knotted muscles.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.15" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">6. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>knot</strong> in a piece of wood is a small hard area where a branch grew.</span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.16" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">7. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>knot</strong> is a unit of speed. The speed of ships, aircraft, and winds is measured in knots.</span><span class="orth"><q>  They travel at speeds of up to 30 knots.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.18" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">8. phrase</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you <strong>tie</strong> <strong>yourself</strong> <strong>in knots</strong>, you get very confused and anxious.</span> (<span class="lbl register">informal</span>)<span class="orth"><q>  The press agent tied himself in knots trying to apologise.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="knot_1.20" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">9. phrase</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you say that two people <strong>tie the knot</strong>, you mean that they get married.</span> (<span class="lbl register">informal</span>)<span class="orth"><q>  Len tied the knot with Kate five years ago.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div></div>

    <a id="lump_1"></a><h1 class="orth h1_entry">lump<span class="pron">(l<span class="underline"></span>mp<span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for lump" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/325/32536/32536.mp3"></a>

<div class="inflected_forms"><span class="var">Word forms:</span> <span class="infl">lumps</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for lump" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/325/32547/32547.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">lumping</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for lump" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/325/32546/32546.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">lumped</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for lump" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/325/32542/32542.mp3"></a>
</span></div>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <div id="lump_1.1" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>lump</strong> <strong>of</strong> something is a solid piece of it.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">of</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  The potter shaped and squeezed the lump of clay into a graceful shape.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">of</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  ...a lump of wood.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  They used to buy ten kilos of beef in one lump.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="lump_1.5" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>lump</strong> on or in someone's body is a small, hard swelling that has been caused by an injury
               or an illness.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">on</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  I've got a lump on my shoulder.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">in</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  Howard had to have cancer surgery for a lump in his chest.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="lump_1.8" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">3. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>lump</strong> <strong>of</strong> sugar is a small cube of it.</span><span class="orth"><q>  'No sugar,' I said, and Jim asked for two lumps.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="lump_1.10" class="hom"> <span class="xr"> <span class="lbl">see also</span> <span class="xr_ref"><a class="xr_ref_link" href="sugar-lump#sugar-lump_1">sugar lump</a></span></span></div>
   <div id="lump_1.11" class="hom"> <span class="xr"> <span class="lbl">see also</span> <span class="xr_ref"><a class="xr_ref_link" href="lump-sum#lump-sum_1">lump sum</a></span></span></div>
   <div id="lump_1.12" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">6. phrase</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you say that you have a <strong>lump in</strong> your <strong>throat</strong>, you mean that you have a tight feeling in your throat because of a strong emotion
               such as sorrow or gratitude.</span><span class="orth"><q>  I stood there with a lump in my throat and tried to fight back tears.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div>
<div class="re hom-subsec">
   <ul class="sense_list level_1">
      <li> <span class="xr"> See  <span class="xr_ref"><a class="xr_ref_link" href="lump-together#lump-together_1">lump together</a></span></span></li>
   </ul>
</div></div>

    <a id="machinery_1"></a><h1 class="orth h1_entry">machinery<span class="pron">(m<span class="underline">i</span>nri<span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for machinery" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/326/32685/32685.mp3"></a>
</span>)</span></h1>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <div id="machinery_1.1" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. uncount noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> You can use <strong>machinery</strong> to refer to machines in general, or machines that are used in a factory or on a farm.</span><span class="orth"><q>  ...quality tools and machinery.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  ...your local garden machinery specialist.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="machinery_1.4" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. singular noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> <strong>The</strong> <strong>machinery</strong> of a government or organization is the system and all the procedures that it uses
               to deal with things.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">of</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  The machinery of democracy could be created quickly.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div></div>
<//body><//html><html><body><div class="homograph-entry">    
    <a id="mere_1"></a><h1 class="orth h1_entry">mere<span class="pron">(m<span class="underline"></span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for mere" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/338/33885/33885.mp3"></a>
</span>)</span></h1>
<div class="inflected_forms"><span class="var">Word forms:</span> <span class="infl">merest</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for mere" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/338/33887/33887.mp3"></a>
</span></div>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <div class="semantic"><strong>Mere</strong> does not have a comparative form. The superlative form <strong>merest</strong> is used to emphasize how small something is, rather than in comparisons.
   </div>
   <div id="mere_1.1" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. adjective</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> You use <strong>mere</strong> to emphasize how unimportant or inadequate something is, in comparison to the general
               situation you are describing.</span> (<span class="lbl pragmatics">emphasis</span>)<span class="orth"><q>  ...successful exhibitions which go beyond mere success.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  There is more to good health than the mere absence of disease.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  She'd never received the merest hint of any communication from him.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="mere_1.5" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. adjective</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> You use <strong>mere</strong> to indicate that a quality or action that is usually unimportant has a very important
               or strong effect.</span><span class="orth"><q>  The mere mention of food had triggered off hunger pangs.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  The team manager has been quick to clamp down on the merest hint of complacency.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="mere_1.8" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">3. adjective</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> You use <strong>mere</strong> to emphasize how small a particular amount or number is.</span> (<span class="lbl pragmatics">emphasis</span>)<span class="orth"><q>  Sixty per cent of teachers are women, but a mere 5 percent of women are heads and
                  deputies.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div></div>

         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> <strong>Midday</strong> is twelve o'clock in the middle of the day.</span><span class="orth"><q>  At midday everyone would go down to Reg's Cafe.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  It's eight minutes after midday.</q></span></li>

</span>)</span></h1>
<div class="inflected_forms"><span class="var">Word forms:</span> <span class="infl">ministers</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for minister" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/343/34352/34352.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">ministering</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for minister" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/343/34351/34351.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">ministered</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for minister" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/343/34349/34349.mp3"></a>
</span></div>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <div id="minister_1.1" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> In Britain and some other countries, a <strong>minister</strong> is a person who is in charge of a particular government department.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">of</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  When the government had come to power, he had been named minister of culture.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  The new Defence Minister is Senator Robert Ray.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="minister_1.4" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>minister</strong> is a person who officially represents their government in a foreign country and has
               a lower rank than an ambassador.</span><span class="orth"><q>  He concluded a deal with the Danish minister in Washington.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="minister_1.6" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">3. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>minister</strong> is a member of the clergy, especially in Protestant churches.</span><span class="orth"><q>  His father was a Baptist minister.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="minister_1.8" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">4. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you <strong>minister to</strong> people or <strong>to</strong> their needs, you serve them or help them, for example by making sure that they have
               everything they need or want.</span> (<span class="lbl register">formal</span>)<span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> +  <em class="hi">to</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  For 44 years he had ministered to the poor, the sick, the neglected and the deprived.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div></div>

</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">motioned</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for motion" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/351/35146/35146.mp3"></a>
</span></div>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <div id="motion_1.1" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. uncount noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> <strong>Motion</strong> is the activity or process of continually changing position or moving from one place
               to another.</span><span class="orth"><q>  ...the laws governing light, sound, and motion.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  One group of muscles sets the next group in motion.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  The wind from the car's motion whipped her hair around her head.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="motion_1.5" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>motion</strong> is an action, gesture, or movement.</span><span class="orth"><q>  He made a neat chopping motion with his hand.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="motion_1.7" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">3. countable noun</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>motion</strong> is a formal proposal or statement in a meeting, debate, or trial, which is discussed
               and then voted on or decided on.</span><span class="orth"><q>  The conference is now debating the motion and will vote on it shortly.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">against</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  Opposition parties are likely to bring a no-confidence motion against the government.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="motion_1.10" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">4. verb</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you <strong>motion</strong> to someone, you move your hand or head as a way of telling them to do something or
               telling them where to go.</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> +  <em class="hi">for</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  She motioned for the locked front doors to be opened.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n prep/adv]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  He stood aside and motioned Don to the door.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> n to-inf]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  I motioned him to join us.</q></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">V</span> +  <em class="hi">to</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  He motioned to her to go behind the screen.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="motion_1.15" class="hom"> <span class="xr"> <span class="lbl">see also</span> <span class="xr_ref"><a class="xr_ref_link" href="slow-motion#slow-motion_1">slow motion</a></span>, <span class="xr_ref"><a class="xr_ref_link" href="time-and-motion#time-and-motion_1">time and motion</a></span></span></div>
   <div id="motion_1.16" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">6. phrase</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you say that someone <strong>is going through the motions</strong>, you think they are only saying or doing something because it is expected of them
               without being interested, enthusiastic, or sympathetic.</span><span class="orth"><q>  'You really don't care, do you?' she said quietly. 'You're just going through the
                  motions.'</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="motion_1.18" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">7. phrase</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If a process or event is <strong>in motion</strong>, it is happening. If it is set <strong>in motion</strong>, it is happening or beginning to happen.</span><span class="orth"><q>  His job as England manager begins in earnest now his World Cup campaign is in motion.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  Her sharp, aggressive tone set in motion the events that led to her downfall.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="motion_1.21" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">8. phrase</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If someone <strong>sets the wheels in motion</strong>, they take the necessary action to make something start happening.</span><span class="orth"><q>  I have set the wheels in motion to sell Endsleigh Court.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div></div>
<//body><//html><html><body><div class="homograph-entry">    
    <a id="neat_1"></a><h1 class="orth h1_entry">neat<span class="pron">(n<span class="underline">i</span>t<span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for neat" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35881/35881.mp3"></a>
</span>)</span></h1>
<div class="inflected_forms"><span class="var">Word forms:</span> <span class="infl">neater</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for neat" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35882/35882.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="infl">,</span><span class="infl">neatest</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for neat" data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35883/35883.mp3"></a>
</span></div>
<div class="definitions hom-subsec">
   <h2 class="h2_entry">Definitions</h2>
   <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">1. adjective</span> 
   </h3>
   <ol class="sense_list level_0">
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>neat</strong> place, thing, or person is tidy and smart, and has everything in the correct place.</span><span class="orth"><q>  She undressed and put her wet clothes in a neat pile in the corner.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  ...a girl in a neat grey flannel suit.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  Everything was neat and tidy and gleamingly clean.</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatly</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35884/35884.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">adverb</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">ADV</span> with v</span><span class="lbl syntax">, <span class="smallcaps">ADV</span> adj/-ed]</span></span><span class="orth"><q>  He folded his paper neatly and sipped his coffee.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  At the door was a neatly dressed, dignified man.</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatness</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35885/35885.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">uncount noun</span></span><span class="orth"><q>  The grounds were a perfect balance between neatness and natural wildness.</q></span></li>
   </ol>
   <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">2. adjective</span> 
   </h3>
   <ol class="sense_list level_0">
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> Someone who is <strong>neat</strong> keeps their home or possessions tidy, with everything in the correct place.</span><span class="orth"><q>  'That's not like Alf,' he said, 'leaving papers muddled like that. He's always so
               neat.'</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatly</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35884/35884.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">adverb</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">ADV</span> with v]</span></span><span class="orth"><q>  He had maybe a thousand tapes, all neatly labelled and catalogued.</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatness</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35885/35885.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">uncount noun</span></span><span class="orth"><q>  ...a paragon of neatness, efficiency and reliability.</q></span></li>
   </ol>
   <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">3. adjective</span> 
   </h3>
   <ol class="sense_list level_0">
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>neat</strong> object, part of the body, or shape is quite small and has a smooth outline.</span><span class="orth"><q>  ...a faded woman with neat features.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  ...neat handwriting.</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatly</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35884/35884.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">adverb</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">ADV</span> -ed]</span></span><span class="orth"><q>  She was a small woman, slender and neatly made.</q></span></li>
   </ol>
   <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">4. adjective</span> 
   </h3>
   <ol class="sense_list level_0">
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>neat</strong> movement or action is done accurately and skilfully, with no unnecessary movements.</span><span class="orth"><q>  A neat move between Black and Keane left Nigel Clough in the clear, but his shot skimmed
               wide of the far post.</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatly</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35884/35884.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">adverb</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">ADV</span> with v]</span></span><span class="orth"><q>  He watched her peel and dissect a pear neatly, no mess, no sticky fingers.</q></span></li>
   </ol>
   <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">5. adjective</span> 
   </h3>
   <ol class="sense_list level_0">
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> A <strong>neat</strong> way of organizing, achieving, explaining, or expressing something is clever and convenient.</span><span class="orth"><q>  It had been such a neat, clever plan.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  Neat solutions are not easily found to these issues.</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatly</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35884/35884.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">adverb</span><span class="lbl syntax"> [<span class="smallcaps">ADV</span> with v]</span></span><span class="orth"><q>  Real people do not fit neatly into these categories.</q></span></li>
      <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"> <span class="drv">neatness</span><span class="hwd_sound">    <a class="hwd_sound sound audio_play_button" title="Pronunciation for " data-src-mp3="/sounds/3/358/35885/35885.mp3"></a>
</span><span class="gramGrp"> <span class="pos">uncount noun</span></span><span class="lbl syntax"> [+  <em class="hi">of</em>]</span> <span class="orth"><q>  He knew full well he had been outflanked, and he appreciated the neatness of it.</q></span></li>
   </ol>
   <div id="neat_1.32" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">6. adjective</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> If you say that something is <strong>neat</strong>, you mean that it is very good.</span> (<span class="lbl geo">US</span>, <span class="lbl register">informal</span>, <span class="lbl pragmatics">approval</span>)<span class="orth"><q>  'Oh, those new apartments are really neat,' the girl babbled on.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  It'll be neat to have a father and son playing on the same team.</q></span></li>
      </ol>
   </div>
   <div id="neat_1.35" class="hom">
      <h3 class="gramGrp h3_entry"><span class="pos">7. adjective</span> 
      </h3>
      <ol class="sense_list level_0">
         <li class="sense_list_item level_1" style="list-style-type: none"><span class="def"> When someone drinks strong alcohol <strong>neat</strong>, they do not add a weaker liquid such as water to it.</span> (<span class="lbl geo">mainly British</span>)<span class="orth"><q>  He poured himself a brandy and swallowed it neat.</q></span><span class="orth"><q>  He took a mouthful of neat whisky, and coughed.</q></span><div class="semantic">in AM, use <strong>straight</strong></div>
         </li>
      </ol>
   </div>
</div></div>
